This SMS from 'Orange' asks you to subscribe to a new internet package using a USSD code (#222#), which is a legitimate and secure method for telecommunication services. There is no suspicious link or threat.
A legitimate bank will never ask for your OTP (One-Time Password) over the phone. Sharing your OTP gives fraudsters access to your account. This is a vishing (voice phishing) attempt.

This call is from a known official number and relates to a service you requested. The caller is offering to activate it, which is a normal customer service interaction. Always be sure to confirm the number is genuinely official.

This call is from an international number, announces an unexpected large prize, and asks for personal data to 'receive' it. This is a classic scam tactic. Legitimate companies do not award prizes this way.

While companies may need to update your information, they usually do not ask for sensitive details like your National ID number and date of birth over an unsolicited call. It's safer to call the official customer service number to verify.
This call is from the official Vodafone customer service number and refers to a complaint you made. This is a legitimate follow-up. Ensure the number is genuinely official.

"ูุฃุณุจุงุจ ุฃูููุฉุ ุงูุชุญ ุงูููู ุงููุฑูู ููุนุฑูุฉ ุชูุงุตูู ุญุณุงุจู."

ุงููููุฒ.explanation: A bank will not ask you to open an attachment to view account details for 'security reasons'. The file extension '.xlsm' can indicate a macro-enabled Excel file, which is often used to deliver malware. This is a phishing attempt.

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ ุฅูููู ูู: friend@gmail.com
"ุฏู ุตูุฑ ุงูุฑุญูุฉ ุงููู ูุนุฏุชู ุจููุง."
๐ Attachment: photos.zip
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: Even if from a known friend, an unexpected ZIP file containing 'photos' could be malicious. ZIP files are often used to bypass email security and deliver malware. Always verify with the sender through an alternative communication channel if you were not expecting such an attachment.

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ ุฅูููู ุฑุณูู ูู: billing@vodafone.com.eg
"ูุฑูู ูุงุชูุฑุชู ุงูุดูุฑูุฉ."
๐ Attachment: Vodafone_Bill.pdf
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: This email from the official Vodafone billing department and contains a PDF bill, which is a common and legitimate practice. This is safe, but always ensure the sender's email is genuinely from the company.

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ ุฅูููู ูู: unknown@randommail.com
"ุนูุฏู ุฅุดุนุงุฑ ููู ุฌุฏูุงุ ุงูุชุญ ุงูููู ุจุณุฑุนุฉ!"
๐ Attachment: urgent.exe
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: This email is from an unknown sender, creates urgency, and contains an executable file (.exe). Executable files in email attachments are highly suspicious and almost always indicate malware. This is a very clear phishing attempt.

ู ุญุชูู_ุงูุฏุฑุณ: o ููุงูุน ุดุจููุฉ ุจู PayPalุ Vodafone Cashุ ุฃู ุจูุงุจุงุช ุงูุฏูุน ุงูุฅููุชุฑููู.

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ SMS: "ุงุฏูุน ูุงุชูุฑุชู ุงูุดูุฑูุฉ ุงูุขู ุนุจุฑ ุงูุฑุงุจุท:
๐ https://vodafone.com.eg/bill"
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: This SMS provides a link to the official Vodafone Egypt billing page (vodafone.com.eg/bill) using HTTPS. This appears to be a legitimate billing notification, but it's always safest to navigate to the official website directly.

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ ุฅูููู ูู: billing@paypal.com
"ูุฅุชูุงู ุงูุฏูุนุ ุงุณุชุฎุฏู ุงูุฑุงุจุท ุงูุชุงูู:
๐ https://paypal.com/myaccount"
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: This email is from the official PayPal billing address and directs to a legitimate PayPal account page (paypal.com/myaccount). This is a standard notification. Always verify the sender's email and the URL directly.

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ SMS: "ุงุดุญู ุฑุตูุฏู ุงูุขู ุนุจุฑ:
๐ http://vodafone-eg-payment.net"
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: The link 'vodafone-eg-payment.net' is not the official Vodafone Egypt domain, and it uses 'http' instead of 'https'. This is a clear indicator of a fake payment website designed to steal your credentials.

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ ุฅูููู: "ุชู ุชุนููู ุญุณุงุจูุ ุงุฏูุน ููุฑูุง ุนุจุฑ ุงูุฑุงุจุท:
๐ https://paypal-secure-login.co"
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: The link 'paypal-secure-login.co' is a fake domain trying to mimic PayPal. The email uses a threatening tone ('ุชู ุชุนููู ุญุณุงุจู', account suspended) and urges immediate action, which are common phishing tactics.

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ SMS ูู CIB:
"ุชูุฏุฑ ุชุฏูุน ุจุทุงูุฉ ุงูุงุฆุชูุงู ุงูุฎุงุตุฉ ุจูู ูู ุฎูุงู ุชุทุจูู CIB Mobile Banking."
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: This SMS from CIB advises you to use the official CIB Mobile Banking app for payment, which is a secure and legitimate method. There are no suspicious links or urgent requests for personal information.

lessons.ุงุณู _ุงูุฏุฑุณ: ุงูููุฏุณุฉ ุงูุงุฌุชูุงุนูุฉ (Social Engineering)

ุงููููุฒ.explanation: This call creates a sense of urgency and threat ('ูุฅูุง ูุชุชููู ุงูุฎุฏูุฉ') and asks for sensitive personal information (National ID). Utility companies generally do not demand such information immediately over an unsolicited call. This is a social engineering tactic.

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ SMS: "ูุจุฑูู! ุขุฎุฑ ูุฑุตุฉ ูุงุณุชูุงู ุฌุงุฆุฒุชู. ุงุถุบุท ููุง:
๐ http://prize-eg.com"
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: This SMS uses an enticing offer ('ูุจุฑูู!'), creates urgency ('ุขุฎุฑ ูุฑุตุฉ'), and directs to a suspicious link ('prize-eg.com'). These are classic social engineering elements designed to exploit curiosity and fear of missing out.

A legitimate HR department would not ask for sensitive documents like National ID and bank details via an unsolicited email, especially for job application procedures. This is a pretexting scam using the guise of a job offer to collect personal information.
No legitimate bank manager will ask for your OTP (One-Time Password) to stop a transfer. This is a high-pressure social engineering tactic to trick you into revealing a critical security code.

This email from Google is a legitimate security alert, directing you to the official Google accounts page (accounts.google.com). It provides a secure way to review and secure your account. Always verify the domain before clicking.

ู ุญุชูู_ุงูุฏุฑุณ: o ูุณุชุฎุฏููุง ุฃุณูุงุก ุดุฑูุงุช ูุจูุฑุฉ (Vodafone, Amazon, Facebook).

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ SMS: "ูุจุฑูู! ูุณุจุช 10,000 ุฌููู ูู Vodafone. ุงุณุชูู ุฌุงุฆุฒุชู ุนุจุฑ:
๐ http://vodafone-prize.com"
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: This SMS offers an unrealistic prize and directs to a non-official Vodafone domain ('vodafone-prize.com') using HTTP. This is a classic fake giveaway scam designed to steal personal information or credentials.

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ ุฅุนูุงู ุนูู ููุณุจูู: "ุงุฑุจุญ iPhone 15 ูุฌุงููุง! ููุท ุงุถุบุท ูุงุดุชุฑู."
๐ http://free-iphone-eg.net
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: This Facebook ad promises an unrealistic free iPhone and links to a suspicious, non-official domain ('free-iphone-eg.net') using HTTP. Such 'too good to be true' offers are almost always scams.

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ ุฅูููู ุฑุณูู ูู Amazon:
"ุงุดุชุฑู ูู ุงููุณุงุจูุฉ ุงูุดูุฑูุฉ ุนุจุฑ ุตูุญุชูุง ุงูุฑุณููุฉ:
๐ https://www.amazon.com/contest"
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: This email is from the official Amazon domain and directs to a legitimate contest page (amazon.com/contest). If the email sender is verified as Amazon, this would be a safe interaction. Always verify directly.

This SMS offers free credit but then asks for sensitive credit card details. Legitimate companies will never ask for your full card details via SMS for such offers. This is an attempt to steal financial information.

This is a legitimate promotion from a verified Facebook page. Engaging with official and verified social media accounts for contests is generally safe, as long as they don't ask for sensitive personal data outside their platform.

ู ุญุชูู_ุงูุฏุฑุณ: o ุตูุฑ ุฌุฐุงุจุฉ ุฃู ุตุงุฏูุฉ.
o ุงุณุชุฎุฏู ุจุฑุงูุฌ ุญุฌุจ ุงูุฅุนูุงูุงุช (Ad Blocker).

ุงููููุฒ.explanation: This ad uses fear tactics ('ุฌูุงุฒู ูุตุงุจ ุจู 13 ููุฑูุณ!') and urges you to download an app from a suspicious, non-secure domain ('virus-cleaner-now.net'). This is a scareware tactic combined with a fake download link, often leading to malware.
An advertisement on YouTube from an official, verified channel (e.g., indicated by a checkmark) of a reputable company like Microsoft, explaining a new product, is generally legitimate and safe.

This ad promises unrealistic quick money ('ุงูุณุจ 5000 ุฏููุงุฑ ูู ุฃุณุจูุน ูุงุญุฏ!') and directs to a suspicious, non-secure domain ('fast-money-eg.com'). These 'get rich quick' schemes are almost always fraudulent.
This Facebook ad promotes an official offer from Nike and links to the legitimate, secure Nike Egypt website. Advertisements from official sources for genuine promotions are generally safe.

This ad uses vague, sensational language ('ุงูุชุดู ุงูุณุฑ ุงูุฐู ุณูุบูุฑ ุญูุงุชู!') to lure clicks and directs to a suspicious, non-secure domain ('life-secret-now.co'). This is a clickbait tactic designed to lead you to scams or unwanted content.

lessons.ุงุณู _ุงูุฏุฑุณ: ุงูุชุญุงู ุดุฎุตูุฉ ุงูุดุฑูุงุช (Business Impersonation)
ู ุญุชูู_ุงูุฏุฑุณ: o ุฑุณุงูุฉ ุจุฑูุฏ ุฅููุชุฑููู ุฃู SMS ุชุฏูุนู ุฅููุง ูู ุดุฑูุฉ ูุจูุฑุฉ (Microsoft, Google, DHL, Vodafone) ุนุดุงู ุชูุณุจ ุซูุชู.

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ ุฅูููู:
"ูุฑุญุจุงุ ูุฐุง ูุฑูู ุฏุนู Microsoft. ุจุฑุฌุงุก ุชุญุฏูุซ ุญุณุงุจู ููุฑูุง:
๐ http://microsoft-update-secure.com"
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: The email claims to be from Microsoft Support, but the link 'microsoft-update-secure.com' is not an official Microsoft domain and uses HTTP. The urgent call to 'ุชุญุฏูุซ ุญุณุงุจู ููุฑูุง' (update your account immediately) is a common impersonation tactic to pressure users into clicking.

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ SMS:
"ุชู ุดุญู ุทูุจู ูู DHL. ุชุชุจุน ุดุญูุชู ููุง:
๐ https://www.dhl.com/track"
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: This SMS indicates a shipment from DHL and provides a link to the official DHL tracking page (dhl.com/track) using HTTPS. This is a legitimate shipping notification.

This email is a phishing attempt. No legitimate company would ask you to fill out sensitive information in an attached Word file. This is a common tactic to deliver malware or collect personal information.

This email from Apple is a security notification about a new login, directing you to the official Apple ID management page (appleid.apple.com) using HTTPS. This is a legitimate security alert, but always verify the sender's email and URL.
This SMS is attempting to phish for your password under the guise of a security confirmation. No legitimate company will ask for your password via SMS. This is a clear phishing attempt.

lessons.ุงุณู _ุงูุฏุฑุณ: ุงูุชุตูุฏ ุนุจุฑ ุงูุดุจูุงุช ุงูุงุฌุชูุงุนูุฉ (Social Media Phishing)
ู ุญุชูู_ุงูุฏุฑุณ: o ุฑูุงุจุท ูุดุจููุฉ ุฃู ูุตูุฑุฉ (bit.ly, tinyurl).

ุงููููุฒ.explanation: This message uses social engineering to create fear and curiosity by claiming a leaked photo, and directs to a suspicious, non-secure domain ('fb-photo-leak.com'). This is a common social media phishing scam to gain access to your account or personal data.
An ad from a verified Instagram account (indicated by a blue checkmark) of a reputable brand like Adidas, linking to their official, secure website, is a legitimate marketing promotion.

This LinkedIn message offers a job at Google but directs to a suspicious, non-secure domain ('google-careers-eg.net'). Official job offers from major companies would link to their actual careers site using HTTPS. This is a fake job offer used for phishing.

A friend request from a new Facebook account with minimal content, even if it uses a friend's name, is a red flag. It could be an impostor account created by a scammer to gain access to your network or information.
This is a normal message from a friend with a link to a legitimate Instagram post. Always ensure the link is genuine, especially if the message seems out of character for your friend.

lessons.ุงุณู _ุงูุฏุฑุณ: ุงูููุงูุน ุงููุฒููุฉ ููุจููู (Banking Phishing)
ู ุญุชูู_ุงูุฏุฑุณ: o ุฑูุงุจุท ูุฑูุจุฉ ูู ุงูุฃุตู ููู ูููุง ุงุฎุชูุงู ุจุณูุท (ูุซุงู: cibegypt-login.com ุจุฏู cibeg.com).
o ุทูุจ ุจูุงูุงุช ุญุณุงุณุฉ ุจุดูู ูุจุงุดุฑ (ุจุทุงูุฉุ PINุ OTP).

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ SMS:
"ุนููููุง ุงูุนุฒูุฒุ ูุชุฃููุฏ ุญุณุงุจู ูู CIB ุงุฏุฎู ููุง:
๐ http://cibegypt-secure-login.com"
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: The link 'cibegypt-secure-login.com' is a fake domain, and it uses HTTP instead of HTTPS. The urgent request to 'ุชุฃููุฏ ุญุณุงุจู' (confirm your account) is a classic phishing tactic to steal banking credentials.

This email is from QNB and directs to the official QNB website (qnb.com) using HTTPS. While it asks for data updates, it directs to the official site, making it legitimate. Always go directly to the official website if unsure.

The link 'nbeegypt-verify.net' is a fake domain impersonating the National Bank of Egypt, and it uses HTTP. The threatening message ('ุชู ุชุนููู ุญุณุงุจู') and urgent call to action are clear signs of a phishing attempt to steal bank details.
A notification directly from the official CIB mobile application about a transaction is a legitimate and secure way to receive updates on your account. There are no suspicious links or requests.
This SMS confirms a successful transfer to your QNB account without any suspicious links or requests for personal information. This is a legitimate transaction notification.

lessons.ุงุณู _ุงูุฏุฑุณ: Fake Wi-Fi Networks (ุงูุดุจูุงุช ุงููุงุณูููุฉ ุงููุฒููุฉ)
ู ุญุชูู_ุงูุฏุฑุณ: o ุงุณุชุฎุฏู VPN ูุญูุงูุฉ ุงุชุตุงูู.

ุงููููุฒ.explanation: The 'CairoAirport_Free' network is open and unprotected, which is a major security risk. Cybercriminals often set up fake, open Wi-Fi networks to intercept data. The secure network requires a password, as confirmed by customer service.

The 'CafeLatte_Free' network is likely a fake Wi-Fi hotspot set up by an attacker to intercept your data, especially if the official network 'CafeLatte_WiFi' was explicitly identified by staff and is secured.
A public Wi-Fi network should never ask for sensitive information like your ID number to connect. This is a clear attempt to collect personal data through a fake Wi-Fi portal.

A Wi-Fi network that is protected by a password provided by official staff (reception) is likely a legitimate and more secure network for guests. However, always use a VPN on public networks for extra security.

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู: ๐ถ ุดุจูุฉ ุนุงูุฉ ุงุณููุง: Free_Internet_ForAllุ ููุชูุญุฉ ุชูุงููุง ูุจุชุดุชุบู ูู ุบูุฑ ุฃู ุชุณุฌูู.
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: Any completely open and unrestricted public Wi-Fi network, especially with a generic name like 'Free_Internet_ForAll', is highly suspicious. These are often traps set by attackers to monitor your online activity and steal data.

ุงููููุฒ.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ QR ููุฌูุฏ ุนูู ุทุงููุฉ ูุทุนูุ ููุง ูุณุญุชู ูุชุญ ูููุน ุฑุณูู:
๐ https://www.starbucks.com/menu
ุงููููุฒ.explanation: A QR code in a restaurant that leads to the official menu on the Starbucks website (https://www.starbucks.com/menu) is legitimate. Always verify that the URL is official before proceeding.

This QR code on a street advertisement promises instant money and leads to a suspicious, non-secure domain ('win-cash-fast.net'). Unrealistic promises and suspicious URLs are hallmarks of a QR code phishing (quishing) scam.

A QR code on a physical menu that directs to a non-official or suspicious domain ('cafe-menu-eg.com') is a red flag. It could be a quishing attack where a fake QR code has been placed over a legitimate one.

A QR code on an official bank statement that leads to the bank's legitimate and secure payment portal (https://www.nbe.com.eg/payment) is safe. However, always double-check the URL to ensure it is the genuine bank website.

This QR code on a metro advertisement promises an official app but leads to a suspicious, non-secure domain ('metro-app-download.co'). Official apps should only be downloaded from trusted app stores, not through direct links from QR codes.

lessons.ุงุณู _ุงูุฏุฑุณ: ุงูุชุตูุฏ ุงููุณุชูุฏู (Spear Phishing)

ุงููููุฒ.explanation: This is a spear-phishing attempt. The email is personalized and appears to be from your manager, but the link 'company-report-secure.net' is a fake domain and uses HTTP. The urgency to review a 'report immediately' is a tactic to bypass critical thinking.
A message from a confirmed colleague asking for a meeting link is a normal work interaction. However, if the request is unusual or urgent, it's always best to verify through an alternative channel.

This is a highly targeted spear-phishing email. The slight misspelling in the HR email address is designed to be overlooked, and the urgent request to 'update bank details' is a direct attempt to steal financial information. Always verify such requests through official channels.
This email from the electricity company provides a link to their official and secure website (moee.gov.eg). This is a legitimate notification for bill availability.
This SMS is suspicious as it mentions an attachment (Word file) for conference details, which is a common tactic to deliver malware or collect personal information. Be cautious with such messages.

lessons.ุงุณู _ุงูุฏุฑุณ: ุงูุชุตูุฏ ุนุจุฑ Deepfake / AI

ุงููููุฒ.explanation: This is a deepfake/AI voice scam. The attacker uses AI to mimic your manager's voice, creating urgency ('ููุฑูุง') for a large financial transfer. Always verify such requests through a different, confirmed communication channel, like a video call or an official email.
A video from an official, verified page of a legitimate bank (National Bank of Egypt) explaining a new service is safe. Official channels are used for genuine communications.

This is a deepfake/AI voice scam attempting to trick you into giving up an OTP. Your friend would never ask for an OTP, especially not claiming it was 'sent by mistake'. Always verify sensitive requests via a different channel.

An ad from an unverified YouTube channel featuring a celebrity promoting an unrealistic investment scheme is likely a deepfake/AI-generated scam. Celebrities are often impersonated to lend credibility to fraudulent schemes. Always verify investment opportunities through official, reputable financial advisors.

A phone call from the bank's official, published hotline number (19623) to verify a transaction is a legitimate security measure. However, be cautious if you receive an unsolicited call and are asked for sensitive information; it's always best to call them back on a verified number.

ู ุญุชูู_ุงูุฏุฑุณ: o ุดุจูุงุช Wi-Fi
โข ูุทููุจ ููู ุชูููุฒ: Safe ุฃู Phishing.

ุงููููุฒ_ุงูููุงุฆู.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ SMS:
"ุนุฒูุฒู ุงูุนูููุ ุจุฑุฌุงุก ุชุญุฏูุซ ุจูุงูุงุชู ููุฑูุง ูุชุฌูุจ ุฅููุงู ุงูุฎุฏูุฉ:
๐ http://nbeegypt-login-secure.com"
ุงููููุฒ_ุงูููุงุฆู.explanation: The link 'nbeegypt-login-secure.com' is a fake domain, and the use of 'http' makes it insecure. The urgent and threatening language ('ูุชุฌูุจ ุฅููุงู ุงูุฎุฏูุฉ') is a common phishing tactic. Always verify directly with the bank.
This is a legitimate advertisement from a verified Adidas account, linking to their official, secure Egyptian website. Official promotions from verified sources are generally safe.

ุงููููุฒ_ุงูููุงุฆู.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ถ ุดุจูุฉ Wi-Fi ูู ูุทุงุฑ ุฏุจู:
โข DubaiAirport_WiFi (ูุญููุฉ ุจูููุฉ ูุฑูุฑ ูุนููุฉ ูู ุงูููุญุงุช ุงูุฑุณููุฉ).
โข Free_DubaiAirport (ููุชูุญุฉ ุจุฏูู ุฃู ุญูุงูุฉ).
ุงููููุฒ_ุงูููุงุฆู.explanation: The 'Free_DubaiAirport' network is an open, unsecured Wi-Fi network, which is often a trap. Always connect to official, password-protected networks from trusted sources, like the one with a password announced on official boards.

This email is a phishing attempt. No legitimate company would ask you to install a security update via an attached Word file. This is a common tactic to deliver malware or collect personal information.

ุงููููุฒ_ุงูููุงุฆู.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ QR ุนูู ูููู ูุทุนูุ ุจููุชุญ ูููุน ุฑุณูู:
๐ https://www.starbucks.com/menu
ุงููููุฒ_ุงูููุงุฆู.explanation: A QR code on a restaurant menu that directs to the official and secure website of Starbucks is legitimate. Always double-check the URL after scanning.

This is a deepfake voice scam. The urgent request for a large financial transfer, even if the voice sounds like your manager, needs to be verified through a separate, trusted communication method (e.g., a direct call to their known number, not a callback to the same number).

A message from a known friend asking for a meeting link is a normal social interaction. However, if the message seems out of character or requests sensitive information, always verify with your friend through another channel.

ุงููููุฒ_ุงูููุงุฆู.ุงูุณุคุงู:
๐ฉ ุฅูููู ูู Google Careers (ุงูุนููุงู: hr@google-careers.com):
"ูุจุฑูู! ุชู ุงุฎุชูุงุฑู ูููุงุจูุฉ ุนูู. ุณุฌู ุจูุงูุงุชู ููุง:
๐ http://google-careers-eg.net"
ุงููููุฒ_ุงูููุงุฆู.explanation: The email claims to be from Google Careers, but the sender's domain 'google-careers.com' is not official, and the link 'google-careers-eg.net' is also fake and uses HTTP. This is a fake job offer designed to phish for personal information.
A notification directly from the official mobile banking app is a legitimate way to receive transaction alerts. There are no suspicious elements here.
